Research article Iridium complex immobilized on covalent triazine framework derived from biomass as a recyclable catalyst for the dehydrogenation of formic acid Xiaozhong Chen Methodology Investigation Data curation a Guoqiang Zhao Software a Beixuan Dong Resources a Feng Li Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Funding acquisition a b ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science & Technology, Nanjing 210094, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nanjing University of Science & Technology Nanjing 210094 PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science & Technology, Nanjing 210094, PR China b State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, PR China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 PR China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The first example of covalent triazine frameworks derived from biomass was designed and synthesized. Furthermore, an iridium complex Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass was prepared by the coordinative immobilization of [Cp*IrCl2]2 on the synthesized covalent triazine framework. In the presence of Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass (0.03 mol % Ir), the reaction was carried out for 24 min at 80 °C and an almost complete dehydrogenation of formic acid with an initial TOF of 7627 h−1 was observed. Further experiments confirmed that heterogeneous catalyst Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass and its homogeneous analog [Cp*Ir(pyridine)Cl2] have approximate catalytic activity. Moreover, catalytic activity of Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass is well maintained during six runs. ©2024 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. Keywords Covalent triazine framework Biomass Iridium Recyclable Dehydrogenation of formic acid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The development of hydrogen as renewable energy has attracted increasing attention in both academia and industry [1]. Formic acid has emerged as a promising candidate for hydrogen storage because of its favorable properties. Formic acid, which contains 53 g of hydrogen per liter (or 4.4 wt%), is handled, stored and transported easily and safely [2]. Moreover, formic acid is available from biomass conversion or carbon dioxide reduction [3]. Although the decomposition of formic acid to H2 and CO2 was discovered in 1967 by Coffey using an iridium phosphine complex [4], the transformation has been investigated extensively only in the past decade. A series of homogeneous transition metal catalysts, such as iron [5], rhodium [6], ruthenium [7], iridium [8] and other metal complexes [9] have exhibited highly catalytic activity for the dehydrogenation of formic acid. However, the practical application is still highly limited because homogeneous catalysts usually could not be recycled. As a result of it, a variety of heterogeneous catalysts have been developed, such as phosphine modified MCM-41 supported Ru-mTPPTS complex [10], SiO2 functionalized with various heteroatom donor ligands-supported Ru complexes [11], phosphine modified SiO2 supported Fe(II) complex [12], and phosphine and bipyridine containing porous polymers-supported Ru complexes [13]. However, the catalytic efficiency of these heterogeneous catalysts is typically much lower compared to homogeneous catalysts. Recently, covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) have attracted much attention because they have high stability in both acidic and basic media, large pore volumes and high surface areas [14]. CTFs supported-Ir, Rh, Ru, Ni complexes been applied to a series of catalytic transformations, such as hydrogenation of CO2 to formate, C–H borylation reactions and transfer hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds [15]. In particular, Goesten and Gascon [16], Yoon [17] and their co-workers have synthesized CTFs supported-Ir or Rh complexes and utilized them as recyclable catalysts for the dehydrogenation of formic acid (Scheme 1 , left). However, CTFs were usually prepared through the ionothermal or superacid hard-template assisted polymerization of a variety of dinitriles as monomers derived from fossil resources. We have developed a series of environmentally friendly organic reactions, such as hydrogen autotransfer process [18], acceptorless dehydrogenative coupling [19] and hydrogenation [20] using homogeneous catalysts. More recently, we have reported a series of catalytic transformations using heterogenous catalysts [21]. Herein, we wish to describe the design, synthesis and characterization of a new-type of covalent triazine framework derived from 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) (Scheme 1, right), which is a versatile platform of lignocellulosic biomass for the synthesis of chemicals, lubricants, fuels and polymers [22]. To the best of our knowledge, the synthesized material represents the first example of covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) from biomass. Furthermore, an iridium complex Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass was prepared by the coordinative immobilization of [Cp*IrCl2]2 on the synthesized covalent triazine framework and was found to be an efficient recyclable catalyst for the dehydrogenation of formic acid. 2 Result and discussion The synthetic route for the designed Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass was outlined in Scheme 2 . The reaction between the commercial 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), which are easily obtained by the oxidation of 5-(hydroxymethyl)furfural (HMF) [23], NH2OH·HCl (3 equiv) and NaOAc (3 equiv) was carried out in H2O under reflux for 12 h to afford 2,5-diformylfuran oxime in 80 % yield. In the presence of molecular sieve (4 Å), Ru-catalyzed dehydration of 2,5-diformylfuran oxime proceeded in CH3CN at 80 °C for 5 h to give 2,5-dicyanofuran in 75 % yield [24,25]. Furthermore, the mixture of furan-2,5-dicarbonitrile and ZnCl2 was heated in a sealed ampule at 400 °C for 48 h to form a black solid. The appearance of the triazine group (1620 cm−1 and 1432 cm−1) and absence of cyanide group (2230 cm−1) were identified by FTIR spectrum, supporting the formation of CTF-biomass material (Fig. S1). The TGA curve showed the weight loss of 10 % at 450 °C, indicating its high stability (Fig. S2). Furthermore, the metallization of CTF-biomass with [Cp*IrCl2]2 proceeded at CH2CH2/CH3OH (v/v = 1:1) for 12h in 90 °C to give Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass (Scheme 1, Fig. 1 (a)). The PXRD analysis of CTF-biomass and Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass showed a diffraction peak at 21.2° (Figure S3), supporting the fact that both are amorphous materials. The absence of a metal peak revealed that the Ir moiety is uniformly dispersed in the CTF-biomass. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis showed that CTF-biomass and Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass are irregular morphologies (Fig. S4, Fig. 1(b) and Fig. S5(a)). In addition, the homogeneous distribution of Ir and Cl atoms throughout the CTF-biomass support was observed by the energy dispersive spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) mapping (Fig. 1(c), Fig. 1(d) and Fig. S6). The actual loading amount of Ir on CTF-biomass was determined to be 5.9 wt% by the inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) analysis (Table S1). Furthermore, the surface properties of CTF-biomass and Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass were examined by the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method (Fig. 2 ). Their N2 sorption isotherm exhibited type 1 isotherm with both meso- and micro-pores. After the incorporation of [Cp*IrCl2]2 to CTF-biomass, the BET surface and pore volume were reduced to 231 m2/g and 0.14 cm3/g from 667 m2/g and 0.26 cm3/g, respectively, which is still porous enough for the facile diffusion of HCOOH into catalytic sites (Table S1). To understand the coordination environment of the Ir cation in CTF-biomass, XPS measurements were conducted and these results are referenced to the C-1 s value of 284.6 eV. The Ir-4f7/2 electron-binding energy (EBE) was found to be 62.1 eV, which is 0.6 eV lower than that of IrCl3 (62.7 eV) [26]. It indicates that N and Cp* ligands donate electron density to the Ir cation. For comparison, the Ir-4f7/2 EBE value of homogeneous catalyst [Cp*Ir(pyridine)Cl2] is also proven to be 62.1 eV, indicating that both Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass and [Cp*Ir(pyridine)Cl2] have similar coordination environments around the Ir cation (Fig. 3 , Fig. S9. With the synthesized Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass in hand, we examined its catalytic activity for the dehydrogenation of formic acid (Table 1 ). In the presence of Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass (0.03 mol % Ir), the dehydrogenation of HCOOH (1.0 M) was carried out at 80 °C for 120 min, only 30 % conversion was found (Table 1, entry 1). To adjust pH of reaction system, 0.5 to 5 equiv of HCOONa was added to HCOOH solution (Table 1, entries 2–6). When the ratio of HCOONa/HCOOH (SF/FA) is up to 2:1 (pH = 4), the maximum initial TOF of 7627 h−1 was achieved (Table 1, entry 4). Decreasing reaction temperature to 70 °C and 60 °C, the initial TOF was decreased to 5012 h−1 and 3269 h−1, respectively (Table 1, entries 7–8). As the catalyst loading increased to 0.045 mol% Ir and 0.06 mol% Ir, complete dehydrogenation of formic acid required only 20 min and 13 min, respectively (Table 1, entries 9–10). Using homogenous catalyst [Cp*Ir(pyridine)Cl2] instead of Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass under same conditions (Table 1, entry 4), initial TOF was found be 7930 h−1, indicating that heterogeneous catalyst Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass and homogeneous catalyst [Cp*Ir(pyridine)Cl2] have approximate catalytic activity. In all cases, the evolved gas was confirmed to be an equimolar mixture of H2 and CO2 without detectable levels of CO (Fig. S10). Apparently, the reaction undergoes the dehydrogenation rather than the dehydration, making the system suitable for the application to fuel cell, in which CO poisoning of electrodes could be prevented [27]. Based on experimental results, a possible mechanism was proposed for the dehydrogenation of formic acid catalyzed byCp*Ir@CTF-biomass (Scheme 3 ). The initial step involved the formation of an unsaturated species A@CTF-biomass through the elimination of Cl− from Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass. Then, the resulting species A@CTF-biomass was coordinated with HCOO− to give the species B@CTF-biomass. Accompanied with the decarboxylation of HCOO– in species B@CTF-biomass, the iridium-hydride species C@CTF-biomass was formed and CO2 was released. Furthermore, the transfer of hydride from species C@CTF-biomass to H+, which was formed in the step of the dissociation of HCOOH, resulted in the regeneration of catalytic species A@CTF-biomass and the liberation of hydrogen gas. As shown in Fig. 4 , the recyclability of catalyst for the dehydrogenation of formic acid was investigated. After each recycling, the catalyst was recovered by the filtration, was washed thoroughly with methanol and was applied to the next cycle. The activity of catalyst is well maintained during recycling experiments and the conversation of reaction was still up to 90 % in sixth cycle. The recovered catalyst after sixth cycle was further investigated. FT-IR spectrum of the recovered catalyst was similar to the fresh catalyst, indicating functional groups in the original catalyst were maintained (Fig. S1). Similarly, the SEM image and EDS mapping showed that the original morphology and the homogeneous distribution of Ir element in CTF-biomass were maintained as well (Fig. S5(b) and Fig. S7). In addition, the iridium content of the recovered catalyst after the sixth cycle was measured to be 5.72 wt% by ICP-MS analysis, which revealed negligible iridium leaching. 3 Conclusions We have demonstrated the design and synthesis of the first example of covalent triazine frameworks derived from biomass. Furthermore, an iridium complex Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass was prepared by the coordinative immobilization of [Cp*IrCl2]2 on the synthesized covalent triazine framework from biomass. In the presence of Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass (0.03 mol% Ir), the reaction was carried out for 24 min at 80 °C and an almost complete dehydrogenation of formic acid with an initial TOF of 7627 h−1 was observed. Further experiments confirmed that heterogeneous catalyst Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass and its homogeneous analog [Cp*Ir(pyridine)Cl2] have approximate catalytic activity. Moreover, catalytic activity of Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass is well maintained during six runs. Notably, this research exhibited the potential of the utilization of biomass conversion for the constrution of covalent triazine frameworks. coredata.dc:description: The first example of covalent triazine frameworks derived from biomass was designed and synthesized. Furthermore, an iridium complex Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass was prepared by the coordinative immobilization of [Cp*IrCl2]2 on the synthesized covalent triazine framework. In the presence of Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass (0.03 mol % Ir), the reaction was carried out for 24 min at 80 °C and an almost complete dehydrogenation of formic acid with an initial TOF of 7627 h−1 was observed. Further experiments confirmed that heterogeneous catalyst Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass and its homogeneous analog [Cp*Ir(pyridine)Cl2] have approximate catalytic activity. Moreover, catalytic activity of Cp*Ir@CTF-biomass is well maintained during six runs. ©2024 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
